content: If you're completely done with that account on that computer and don't need access to any emails, including the important ones that you searched for and found, just go to (in Windows) Tools | Account Settings and in the right pane you'll see a Delete button. This will remove the account from Thunderbird but won't affect the messages on the server.

content: After you click the Delete button you'll be presented with a confirmation dialog box that includes a "Remove message data" option, which you will want to choose in this case. After you click the Remove button, everything associated with that account will be deleted from your computer (but not the server.)

content:
I've discovered that adding addressBook and calendar parameters to config-v1.1.xml does not make any difference. The DAV request is always coming to the domain which the email address belongs to.

Request: PROPFIND https://mydomain.com/.well-known/carddav Response: 301 location: https://nextcloud.mydomain.com/.well-known/carddav

Request: PROPFIND https://nextcloud.mydomain.com/.well-known/carddav Response: 301 location: https://nextcloud.mydomain.com/remote.php/dav

Request: PROPFIND https://nextcloud.mydomain.com/remote.php/dav Response: 207 "content-security-policy: default-src 'none';" "content-type: application/xml; charset=utf-8" some xml data

Request: PROPFIND https://mydomain.com/remote.php/dav Response: 404

The last request doesn't make any sense. It contains a part of the address "/remote.php/dav" from the domain it was redirected to, but the request comes to the wrong domain. Is it a bug in Thunderbird? After adding the redirect from https://mydomain.com/remote.php/dav to https://nextcloud.mydomain.com CardDAV service is working.

But I still haven't figured out a way to configure it correctly without going to about:config. I could probably modify the content-security-policy header coming from Nextcloud, but there is a post on Nextcloud forums that warns about danger of doing that, it says that CSP headers should be managed by Nextcloud's PHP code.

content:
re : It has stopped allowing me to easily delete unwanted emails.

It may help to find out what is going on. I'm not sure what it is that you are suddenly finding difficult. Unwanted mail is generally labelled as Junk/Spam and if set up correctly they should be in the 'Spam/Junk' folder. A right click on Spam/Junk folder and select 'Empty Junk' should delete them. After emptying Junk - right click on folder and select 'Compact' to remove all traces.

If you have unwanted mail in eg: Inbox, you can mark as Junk and it should go to the accounts Junk/Spam folder. Or if unwanted mail is in 'Inbox' and you do not want to open it: Right click on email to see a menu. The Mark as Junk icon is at the top - it has a flame icon OR to delete click on the far right Trash icon and it should go into the account Trash folder.

There are several ways to delete an email.

What exactly is the problem ? What method do you normally use ?

re : Further, it is slow as molasses when trying to expand and read emails.

Are you using an Imap or Pop account ?

What Anti-Virus do you use ? I ask because many people allow their AV to scan any file that gets opened. That means Thunderbird can temporarilly be held up because AV has taken control over the file which manifests as a delay in proceedings. A pain in the proverbial. To be honest I advise people to access their Anti-Virus and set up an exemption to not scan the 'Thunderbird' profile folder: eg: C://User/<username>/Appdta/Roaming/Thunderbird After all, you do not want it to fix anything as it might cause data loss. AV products do not understand that one text file may contain hundreds of emails. If you still want it to scan those files, then at the very least do not allow AV to auto fix or quarrantine - tell it to ask what to do so you can stop any action.

Another thought - how frequently do you compact your folders ? Ideally the Inbox, Drafts and Spam/Junk should compacted on a regular basis especially after deleting or moving emails. I manually compact those three folders almost daily because I get quite a few emails. I also use Message Filters to help sort and organise emails into various folders, so a lot of emails get 'moved'. If you do not compact then the email remains in the original file, marked as deleted and hidden. That means the file may be a lot larger than you think. Not compacting can increase the risk of corruption, so it's a good thing to do as housekeeping maintenance.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : My understanding is that the 102 series version works better.

Not sure where you got that information. You need to be aware that some people do not like new designs even if they really are better so they become more vocal. But in reality the majority just get on with and find it's better than they initially thought especially when they realise there are alot more options. You tend to not hear much from those people. I'm using two version of Thunderbird at the moment. One is version 128.14.0esr and the other is beta 145.0b2 I do that because some people are still on the older version and I offer help, so need to know info. The beta means I'm able to test and check for any bugs etc. It also has all the visual data etc that is currently used the 144 version.

My experience is in all the versions and I would not say 102 series is a better option. It was a good version, but will not be using the most up to date security or bug fixes. It also will not have all the new functionalities and design display options. Some people are not aware of the new options. There has also been a huge change in the code as alot has been rewritten. If you go back then you can end up being very out date in a short amount of time.

I would be happy to help to see if something is not set up correctly which improves your experience. Many people have not yet got to grips with the new options and some never realised some older options were still available. eg: The new Unified Toolbar operates over various views such as Mail or Calendar etc and it can be customised in such a way that some new toolbars can be hidden to gain space/declutter. There is also two ways to view the Message List, eg: Table view or Card view. The list is quite lengthy, but if you want to see if you can improve the current situation, then let's see what we can achieve.

You might be think - ah well - it's alright for younger folk they adjust more easily. Sadly, I'm no spring chicken, so I do understand. But, it doesn't stop me from picking it up alot quicker than I may have initally thought.

However, if you really want to go backwards then you would need to do the following. I would always advise that you create a backup before you do this for obvious reasons :)

First make sure Thunderbird is not set up to auto update:

  • Settings > General
  • scroll down to 'Updates' section
  • select option 'check for updates. but let mew choose whether to install them'
  • Do not select/uncheck this option: 'Use a background service to install updates'

Unchecking that last option means even if you accidentally selected to update, the OS will pop up a UAC prompt to ask if you really want to allow the update, so you can say NO and stop it.

  • Exit Thunderbird - this is important.
  • Check computer for updater software

Make sure you do not have any other updater software on computer which may try to override. Some Anti-Virus products do offer auto checks for updates. I use Norton 360 and I know it offers checking for software updates. I had to stop it from checking for a Firefox and Thunderbird update. Let Firefox and Thunderbird control the updates when you say so.

Now access profile

  • In Windows search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  • Select '%Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming'
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder and paste in safe location such as an external hardrive or another partition eg: D: drive - this will be the backup.
  • Select 'Thunderbird' to see contents
  • Select 'Profiles'
  • Select the 'profile name' folder
  • Look for delete the 'compatibility.ini' file.
  • Uninstall Thunderbird.
  • Get a download from the appropriate version link - choose eg: win64 for a Windows OS. Then choose prefered language eg: en-GB = English British and then click on the 'Thunderbird version exe' file link to download.

Version 102.15.1

  • https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/102.15.1/

Version 128.14.0

  • https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/128.14.0esr/

creator: p.knotig

content:
Zkontroluj několik věcí:

Webmail / jiný klient: Otevři si schránku přes web (např. Seznam, Gmail, Centrum…). Jestli tam zpráva s přílohou je, ale v Thunderbirdu chybí, problém je v nastavení nebo v doplňku Thunderbirdu.

Filtry a antivir: Podívej se, jestli nemáš aktivní filtr, který maže nebo přesouvá zprávy s přílohou. Některé antiviry (např. Avast) také umí blokovat e-maily s přílohami.

Zobrazení v Thunderbirdu: V Nástroje → Nastavení účtů → Synchronizace a úložiště zkontroluj, jestli nemáš nastaveno “Nestahovat přílohy” nebo příliš malý limit pro stahování.

Zkus zrušit doplňky: V nouzovém režimu Thunderbirdu („Spustit v nouzovém režimu“) zjistíš, jestli přílohy nezačnou chodit po vypnutí rozšíření.

Protokol účtu: Pokud používáš POP3, může být problém s mazáním starých zpráv ze serveru. U IMAP by měly být přílohy vždy viditelné i přes webmail.

content: Actually, with IMAP, copies are on your PC. The main issue to remember is that they are deleted from PC if deleted from server. content: I believe this relates to the popstate.dat file that tells thunderbird the next email to download. This is to prevent downloading messages that have been previously downloaded. More info is at https://kb.mozillazine.org/Popstate.dat.

I found an inelegant solution. I created my same email account in Thunderbird as IMAP. I simply find the missing email and click/drag it to my POP account. FYI - My POP account is my email filing & storage system so I do not have to be concerned about gmail file sizes or IMAP deleted emails.

Thanks for all the assistance.

content:
Si, se Lascia i messaggi sul server non è spuntata, Thunderbird scarica la posta e poi la cancella dal server. Tuttavia alla configurazione di un account su Thunderbird, questa voce è attiva per cui devi averla disattivata tu volontariamente.

L'opzione Lascia i messaggi sul server inoltre suggerisce che stai usando il protocollo POP3 per cui non è possibile ricaricare direttamente la posta sul server (per fare questo si utilizza il protocollo IMAP). Puoi però inoltrare al tuo stesso indirizzo in messaggi di cui vuoi avere una copia anche sul server.

content:
If this is only a temporary situation and you will get a replacement computer very soon, maybe you would be content to just use webmail in the meantime.

Is there any way you can get some files off the broken computer and copy them to a flash drive or something? If so, you could copy your Thunderbird profile from that machine to the Dell. This would be the best solution, as you won't risk losing any emails.

If not, you can install Thunderbird on the old Dell, and create a new account that will connect to your email service. You will then be able to retrieve any mail currently on that mail server. Further advice depends on the answer to this question:

Was the broken computer connected to the mail server via IMAP or POP3? Or do you not know? Once we know that, we can suggest the next steps toward recovery.

The reason that answer is important is that if it was IMAP, copies of your old mail and folders will still be on the server. If it was POP3, the old mail only exists on your broken computer and will permanently lost if you can't get it off the old hard disk.
creator: rednoise

content: My dell has nothing it was reset. The broken computer has files and I am able to copy to a flash drive. Email is IMAP. What directories do I need to look for to get the data copied to the Dell? Thank you so much!
creator: lunartic_cls

content:
OK, good! You have a good chance of recovering everything.

On the broken computer, look in the folder: 

    C:\Users\<your Windows user name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles

- There you'll see one or more sub-folders, one of which is your profile. If you're not sure which one it is, look inside and see which one has the most recent files. Make a note of the name of that folder.

- Copy that folder to your flash drive. It can be quite large, so make sure your flash drive has enough room.

- Install Thunderbird to the Dell. It would be best if you can install the same version as on the broken computer.

- Copy your profile folder from the flash drive to the equivalent location on the Dell.

- On the Dell, press <Windows key>+R to bring up the Run dialog box. In the text box type:

thunderbird -profilemanager or thunderbird -p

to start Thunderbird's Profile Manager.

- Click the Create Profile... button, then Next. Give the new profile any name you like. Then click the "Choose Folder..." button.

- You will now see the folder you copied over from the broken computer. Select that folder and choose the "Select Folder" button. You will then be returned to the Create Profile Wizard dialog box. Click the Finish button. You will be returned to the Profile Manager.

- Make sure your newly-created profile is selected and click the Start Thunderbird button. You may want to check the "Use selected profile without asking at startup" option.


If everything has gone according to plan, you will now see Thunderbird much as you're used to seeing it on the broken computer.


Here's Mozilla's official instructions for the procedure we just did. Their method is somewhat different than mine. but but the end result is the same:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer
creator: rednoise

content:
Can I assume you're aware that there are global junk controls in Settings, plus controls for each account that can override the Global ones?

There's also the Message Filters feature that can mark messages as spam. Have you checked them out? A poorly-formed filter rule could mark everything as spam.

You can't assume that the "Thunderbird thinks this message is Junk mail" banner means that Thunderbird is making that decision. You get that same banner even for messages that were moved to the junk folder by the mail system.
creator: rednoise

content:
As I said in my original message, junk filters are turned off globally and for each account, so yes I am aware of those. Additionally, there are NO filters set up of any kind in my accounts. As I mentioned, this started suddenly several days ago after years of not having this problem and not changing anything in my setup. Also, I am aware that gmail considering mail as junk would trigger a notice from Thunderbird, but as I also indicated gmail is NOT filtering and is not flagging these messages as junk. Further, no messages are being sent to the Junk folder -- they are all appearing in my Inbox and are getting flagged as junk.

I've tried everything I could think of, considering that I've used this client for many years and have become quite familiar with its' functionality, and I'm at a loss to understand why it is doing this. I am only left with the possibility that it is something within the Thunderbird application that is causing this issue and I can't figure out how to stop it.
creator: sbischof2200

content:
Maybe the adaptive junk filter database has become corrupt? I used to use other Bayesian email filters, and that happened once or twice, resulting in erratic detection. I believe choosing the "Reset Training Data" button will fix that, though you will have to train it from scratch again.

And maybe turning on the "Enable adaptive junk filter logging" option will reveal something. I've never tried that.
creator: rednoise

content: Well, I did try the "Reset Training Data" feature already, but it made no difference. Right now, since it's not supposed to be filtering anything the junk filter logs have nothing in them, however that option was not selected (since I wasn't filtering). I've turned the logging on, but I'm not expecting anything to show up since there is no filtering/detection of any kind. I'll have to check it when I get more emails flagged as junk to see if it logs anything.
creator: sbischof2200

content: A brute-force possibility would be to remove the account from Thunderbird and re-add it. It could be painful or not depending on how many messages are on the server.
creator: rednoise

content: All my messages are kept on the mail servers. I only use Thunderbird as a client (nothing is stored locally), so it would take quite some time to reload all the messages for all my accounts (5) in this application, and set up each account all over again. Also, this is a relatively new computer, so Thunderbird hasn't been active on this pc for very long -- I had to install and set it up from scratch, so I'd really hate to have to do that all over again so soon. I prefer Thunderbird, but unfortunately if I had to start over with it, especially with no guarantee it would solve the problem, I might just as well find another client to use.

Well, none of the suggestions so far has eliminated the problem. In fact, despite telling Thunderbird that email from senders is 'Not Junk', it continues to mark the same senders as junk, and I have to select the button to tell it that it isn't junk every time.

This is becoming impossible to manage.

content:
If you've disabled all TB junk controls for all accounts, the junk/spam filtering is being done by the mail provider:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1404881
creator: sfhowes

content: Unfortunately, we have already considered that possibility (and double-checked it) and there are no spam or junk filters being applied in my gmail accounts. Also, even if they were, the affected mail messages would be moved into the spam or junk mail folders on the mail server and I'd see them there -- all of the mail I am discussing here is delivered into my Inbox. Even mail that I indicate is 'Not Junk' by clicking the appropriate button on the preview pane, gets filtered again as possible junk the next time there is a message from that sender.

content: Also, as a side note, if the messages were being flagged by gmail, the flame icon would be showing as grayed out, these messages are all showing the orange flame, indicating that Thunderbird is flagging them...
creator: sbischof2200

content:
Deleted messages don't really go away until you compact.

TB Menu Bar > File > Compact Folders If you don't see the menu bar on top, press the ALT key.

It might take a while.
creator: siffemoz

content: Thank you, Ed! I did as you suggested (and I did have to press Alt to get the menu bar). When I clicked 'Compact,' the menu bar disappeared. Is that normal? Does it mean it'll get around to compacting at some point?
creator: RoseQueen

content: Compacting does explicitly expunge messages on the server as a part of the process, but simply setting the option in account settings >server setting to expunge the inbox on exit and actually restarting Thunderbird on a fairly regular basis clears cup most of the issues that would be occuring here. It is a good practice if you have limited server storage.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Thanks, Matt. That's something I definitely don't do, but I'll train myself to do that!
